Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides partial support for participation by U.S.-based mathematicians at an international conference in geometric topology to be held in Tuscany, Italy, during June 5-9, 2017. Topology is the study of the properties of spaces that do not depend on a way to measure distance; this conference focuses on those spaces that arise in geometric contexts such as surfaces and three-dimensional spaces (with the universe we live in being one example). The conference will feature both research talks on the latest developments in the area and three mini-courses designed for advanced graduate students and other early career mathematicians. The conference will provide an opportunity for those conducting cutting-edge research to present their results and a venue for discussion and collaboration among established researchers and junior mathematicians in the field. This award will allow a significant number of U.S.-based early-career mathematicians to attend, and a majority of this funding will support these mathematicians.

The conference will focus primarily on low-dimensional hyperbolic geometry, and, more generally, geometric structures on manifolds. Mini-courses on character varieties and knot symmetries, arithmetic hyperbolic 3-manifolds, and renormalized volume will provide an introduction to several of the emerging trends in the field. This will be complemented by research talks from a distinguished international group of speakers. More information on the conference can be found at
http://www.dm.unipi.it/~martelli/Cortona2017/Cortona.html

POR.DRECONTENT:
A meeting was held on Geometric Topology in Cortona, Italy from June 4-10, 2017. The focus of the meeting was hyperbolic geometry. Italy has a strong tradition in hyperbolic geometry starting with Roberto Bennedetti and Carlo Petronio and continuing with their students Francesco Bonsante, Stefano Francaviglia, Roberto Frigerio and Bruno Martelli who are now training a new generation of mathematicians. The conference had large groups of participants from Italy and throughout Europe along with a contingent of US based mathematicians, many of whose participation was supported by this grant. Along with the formal presentations the meeting provided the opportunity for many informal discussions to share research among this international group.

The meeting featured three, 3-hour mini-courses on:

- "Character varieties and knot symmetries", by Joan Porti

- "Arithmetic hyperbolic manifolds", by Alan Reid

- "Renormalized volume", by Jeff Brock, Ken Bromberg and Jean-Marc Schlenker

These mini-courses were targeted at graduate students and other early career mathematicians to introduce them to these emerging topics in the field.

There were also talks by Martin Bridgeman, Jeffrey Dancinger, Colin Guillarmou, Anna Lenzhen, Sara Maloni, Yair Minsky, Kate Petersen, Maria Beatrice Pozzetti and Andrea Seppi who reported on their latest research.

More information about the meeting can be found at the website:

http://people.dm.unipi.it/martelli/Cortona2017/Cortona.html
